column1: San Ramon (Spanish: San Ramón; Spanish for '"Saint Raymond"') is a city in Contra Costa County
column4: located within the San Ramon Valley
column5: and 34 miles east of San Francisco. San Ramon's population was estimated as 75
column6: 995 in 2019 by the US Census Bureau
column7: making it the 4th largest city in Contra Costa County

column1: San Ramon is home to the headquarters of Chevron Corporation
column3: the West Coast headquarters of AT&T
column4: the Global Software Center of General Electric
column5: as well as the San Ramon Medical Center. Major annual events include the Art and Wind Festival on Memorial Day weekend and the Run for Education in October.

column3: San Ramon was designated a Tree City USA.

column1: San Ramon is adjacent to Danville
column4: California
column5: to the south. Unincorporated county lands border San Ramon to the east and west. It is located around 500 feet (150 m) above sea level. Mount Diablo flanks the city to the northeast and is prominently visible from almost all parts of the city. The Las Trampas Regional Wilderness borders San Ramon's extreme northwest
column6: at the northern end of Bollinger Canyon. The smaller Bishop Ranch Regional Preserve straddles San Ramon's western border
column7: located approximately between Interstate 680 and the Alameda County line.

column1: The topography of San Ramon is varied
column2: featuring a mix of the rolling hills of the Diablo Range and the flatter basin of the San Ramon Valley. The city is predominantly urban and residential with many new housing developments
column3: however much of the land around the city's perimeter regions remains undeveloped
column4: and is covered by grasslands and oak tree orchards. During the drier months the grasses are golden
column5: but with the precipitation of winter and spring

column1: San Ramon's weather typifies a Mediterranean climate
column3: and moderate. Summers are warm to hot and dry
column4: while winters are mild or cool
column5: wet and rather short. Its weather is similar to the adjacent cities of Danville
column6: Dublin and Pleasanton. Fog can be infrequent but occurs normally in the western reaches of the city
column7: at the eastern mouth of Crow Canyon
column8: through which marine weather patterns funnel in from the San Francisco Bay via Castro Valley. It usually burns off by mid-to-late morning.

column1: Average January temperatures are a maximum of 58 °F (14 °C) and a minimum of 36 °F (2 °C).  Average July temperatures are a maximum of 83 °F (28 °C) and a minimum of 56 °F (13 °C). January is normally the wettest month
column2: averaging 5.20 inches (132 mm) of precipitation and followed by March
column3: is the second wettest month averaging 4.15 inches (105 mm) of precipitation . July is usually the driest month
column4: with an average of only 0.06 inches (1.5 mm) of precipitation. Snow is extremely rare except for Mount Diablo
column5: but hail occurs a few times in the winter.

column1: The lands now occupied by the City of San Ramon were formerly inhabited by Seunen people
column2: an Ohlone/Costanoan group who built their homes near creeks. Sometime around 1797 they were taken by Mission San José for use as grazing land. In 1834
column3: they were part of the Rancho San Ramon land grant to José María Amador.Amador named San Ramón (Spanish for 'Saint Raymond') not after a real saint but rather after a Native American vaquero who tended mission sheep on the land. Amador added the "San" per Spanish custom.In 1964
column4: Pacific Air Lines Flight 773 crashed near San Ramon after both pilots were shot by a passenger.

column1: San Ramon is governed by a four-body City Council composed of individuals elected to four-year overlapping terms in coordination with a two-year elected mayor. Police services were provided under contract by the Contra Costa County Sheriff's Department until July 1
column3: when the city officially took over providing police services.

column2: the elected representatives are Bill Clarkson (Mayor)
column4: Scott Perkins
column5: Phil O'Loane and David Hudson (Council members).The city of San Ramon is in Contra Costa County.

column5: and provides a healthy tax base for the city. Bishop Ranch is situated on 585 acres once owned by Western Electric
column6: and was farmland before that. Current tenants include the corporate headquarters of Chevron Corporation (formerly ChevronTexaco)
column7: as well the West Coast headquarters of AT&T Inc. (which had been the headquarters of Pacific Bell from about 1983
column8: when it relocated from downtown San Francisco
column9: until the merger with SBC Communications that created the current AT&T). United Parcel Service has a regional distribution center in Bishop Ranch. Toyota  has a regional office and parts distribution center located there. GE Global Research started its Global Software Center in Bishop Ranch in 2011. Bishop Ranch covers the vast majority of "Central San Ramon"

column13: and Bollinger Canyon Road on the south (though several complexes are south of Bollinger).  In December 2016

column1: San Ramon's public schools are part of the San Ramon Valley Unified School District (SRVUSD)
column3: 300 students. The city has 11 elementary schools and four middle schools. The high schools are California and Dougherty Valley High School. An alternative K–12 school is operated by the SRVUSD to support home-schooled students: Venture Independent Study School.

column1: California High School was founded in 1973 and ranked 250th best high school in the United States by Newsweek. Dougherty Valley High School is ranked 42nd within California; it is ranked No. 281 in the national rankings and earned a gold medal.

The San Ramon Library and Dougherty Station Library branches of the Contra Costa County Library and Ramona Library are in San Ramon.
